awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Theoretical and Experimental Investigation of Synthetic Micro/Nano-Swimmers in Shear-thinning Fluids
awd_abstract_narration:
Synthetic swimmers are engineered microscopic or nanoscopic objects that mimic how natural microorganisms swim through their environment.  Synthetic swimmers that can move through biological fluids show great promise in biomedical applications such as drug delivery and microsurgery.  Successful applications of these swimmers to biomedical tasks rely on their ability to move through biological fluids, such as blood, with complex and varying properties that respond to their surroundings. While there have been recent studies on the subject of locomotion in these fluids, much remains to be learned about the influence of directional applied forces or other motions such shaking and agitation, on swimming.  This research project aims to quantify and elucidate the impacts of complex (non-Newtonian) fluid properties on the locomotion of synthetic micro-swimmers. The outcomes will enable the development of micro-robots with robust swimming capabilities for next generation healthcare applications.  The project will integrate research and education through senior design projects and undergraduate research participation. By leveraging existing university programs with new activities derived from the research project, the researchers will provide outreach to approximately 120 high-school students annually.  The project will also support an exhibition entitled "Swallowing a Surgeon" at the California Science Center (Los Angeles, CA) in order to expose the general public to the challenges and progress made towards designing biomedical micro-robots.

In this collaborative research project between Santa Clara University and the California Institute of Technology, computations and experiments will be used to understand locomotion in shear-thinning fluids and to identify effective strategies to account for this non-Newtonian fluid behavior in the design of synthetic swimmers. Existing propulsion mechanisms can be broadly categorized into chemically-powered swimmers that harvest energy from local chemical reactions, and swimmers that require external fields for actuation. In this research project, representative model systems from each category will be studied to evaluate the impacts of shear-thinning rheology on major types of synthetic swimmers at small scales. Theory and experiments will use catalytic motors and flexible magnetic nanowire propellers to provide a comprehensive understanding of how distinct types of non-Newtonian fluid behaviors and their interactions affect locomotion at small scales. The completion of this project will lead to new fundamental knowledge on fluid-structure interactions and phoretic motion in complex fluids. This improved understanding will in turn guide the design of next-generation synthetic swimmers that can move through biological fluids effectively.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Introduction

The movement of microscopic swimmers, such as bacteria and synthetic microrobots, through biological fluids is a topic of immense scientific and medical interest. Unlike simple Newtonian fluids, biological environments such as blood and mucus exhibit complex non-Newtonian properties, including shear-thinning behavior and viscoelasticity. This project aimed to understand the fundamental principles governing microscopic locomotion in these complex fluids and develop strategies for designing synthetic swimmers with biomedical applications. This work was conducted as a collaboration between Santa Clara University, led by PI On Shun Pak, and the California Institute of Technology, led by PI Wei Gao, integrating theoretical modeling and experimental validation. The findings have significant implications for targeted drug delivery, minimally invasive surgery, and real-time biomedical diagnostics.

Intellectual Merit

The project has advanced the fundamental understanding of microscopic locomotion in non-Newtonian fluids. Major achievements include the development of synthetic micro/nanoswimmers designed and characterized using various propulsion mechanisms, including acoustic, magnetic, and chemical propulsion. The research introduced hydrogel-based bioresorbable acoustic microrobots (BAMs) that provide enhanced stability and controlled drug delivery within complex biological environments. Additionally, enzymatic microbubble-powered robots were developed, leveraging protein shell structures and functionalized surfaces to achieve scalable and targeted propulsion. Theoretical and computational models were developed to predict and optimize microswimmer performance in shear-thinning fluids. Simulations demonstrated the influence of non-Newtonian stresses on confined magnetically driven particles, leading to key insights into efficient swimmer design. Machine learning techniques were employed to train microswimmers to adapt to varying fluidic environments. Biomedical demonstrations successfully validated microrobot propulsion in physiological fluids such as human serum and mucus. In vivo testing confirmed the effectiveness of these microrobots for drug delivery and precision medicine applications. These findings were published in high-impact journals such as Science Robotics, Nature Reviews Bioengineering, Advanced Materials, highlighting their significance to the scientific community.

Broader Impacts

The project’s broader impacts extend to education, outreach, and real-world biomedical applications. The collaboration between Caltech, a research-intensive institution, and Santa Clara University, a primarily undergraduate institution, fostered a dynamic research environment. Undergraduate students were actively involved in hands-on research, gaining valuable experience in experimental and computational methodologies. The project supported multiple graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and several REU participant. Research findings were widely disseminated through journal publications, conference presentations, and invited talks at prestigious international forums. Media coverage from outlets such as Caltech News, Physics World, and Yahoo helped bring awareness to the broader public. The insights gained from this research pave the way for future clinical applications of microrobots in non-invasive medical diagnostics and treatment. This work contributes to the ongoing development of precision medicine, enabling targeted therapeutic delivery with minimal side effects.

Conclusion

This project has made significant strides in the development of synthetic microswimmers capable of navigating complex biological environments. By integrating experimental studies with theoretical models, the research has deepened the understanding of non-Newtonian fluid dynamics and provided a roadmap for future biomedical applications. The work not only advances fundamental science but also has the potential to revolutionize medical technology, offering innovative solutions for drug delivery, diagnostics, and minimally invasive surgery.

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2025
Modified by: Wei Gao
